T1 starting to get neuropathy

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎04-17-2014 09:21 PM

Hello,

 

I'm 37 and was diagnosed with T1 a couple years ago - with a bsl of 564. Now have a pump, which I love, and the blood sugar levels are under control (A1C of 7 and below).  However, really starting to feel the effects of neuropathy throughout body in the last few months - everything from hands and arms to tired to pick up my kids, to having problems smiling anymore. Just the feeling like I exercised way too much, but, I haven't exercised except the normal chores of a dad with 5 kids under 8 years old

 

Wondering what to expect in years to come. As a computer programmer, am I going to lose ability to type? Oddly typing doesn't bother me too much, but washing dishes / changing diapers hurts a LOT. My doctor assured me that once sugar is under control I'll be fine, but...I don't trust him (he's young). I'm getting worse as far as muscle stamina..

 

So:

1. Will I get to the point I can't type, losing my career?

2. Does exercise help or hurt neuropathy? Feels like a little exercise makes it sooooo much worse.

 

Thanks for any insight!

Helpful Response Given! Go to this response.

Re: T1 starting to get neuropathy

‎04-18-2014 01:03 PM

Your A1c is only part of the story.  And while most here look for lower than a 7%, it is better than most in the general public.  Aiming for as near non-diabetic levels as possible helps, but you need to avoid th swings.  If you are getting some big spikes, you can still be causing damage even if you average 7.  How much are you testing?  What is your range?  The outlook for complications is heavily impacted by your levels.

 

Exercise helps blood glucose levels, but can be tough with the neuropathy.  It improves circulation which also helps.



You go to school to learn, not for a report card.
You use your meter to learn, not for a report card

Type 1 (LADA).. Novolog/Levemir

Adult onset T1

‎04-18-2014 04:02 PM

You may have neuropathy, but I would also recommend finding a doctor/ therapist to talk to. You have concerns and ohysical symptoms that sound more like depression to me.
It won't surprise you to know that being diagnosed with a chronic illness means you are more likely to experience depression, but what might surprise you is to know that there are very real physical symptoms that can accompany depression.
I don't know where you live, but much of the country had a very tough winter this year - being 'depressed' about the winter isn't the same thing as having mild depression, but they can feed each other. add to that the fact that you have 5 kids under age 8 - you have a lot on your plate! Let your doctor know...
Pam

Diagnosed Type 1 at age 16 months, over 45 years now
Minimed pump and cgm since July '09. Metformin (insulin resistance), levothyroxine(thyroid), losartan (BP)
I have traveled cross country, and to Canada, UK, Kenya, Mexico, Jamaica, Equador/Galapagos islands, and lived in Egypt for a year.
